correction_response: This tweet is somewhat misleading. While it's true that Florida has decided not to offer the new AP African American Studies course, it's not accurate to say it's been "banned". The state's Department of Education has expressed concerns about the course's educational value, but also indicated a willingness to reconsider if the course content changes. The course is a pilot program developed by the College Board, aiming to explore the contributions and experiences of African Americans. It's important to note that it's a humanities course and does not teach theory. https://www.reuters.com/world/us/florida-schools-will-not-offer-ap-african-american-studies-course-2023-01-20/
note_1_text: The new AP African American Studies course is not widely available; it is in a multi-year pilot phase. It is being offered at around 60 high schools in the US this year.    The Florida Department of Education wrote that it would not allow schools to offer the course.     https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/ap-african-american-studies-florida-desantis/    https://apcentral.collegeboard.org/about-ap/how-ap-develops-courses-and-exams/pilot-ap-african-american-studies
note_2_text: There is no "Don't Say Black" policy. African American studies are not banned. Instead, Florida declined to a adopt an advanced placement African American studies course in development by the College Board. This new course was not previously part of the curriculum.    https://www.cnn.com/2023/01/19/politics/ron-desantis-ap-african-american-studies/index.html
